The truth does not free a man,
for no man is free as a result of
his biological inheritan:e, social
limitations, intellectual innocence,
and desire to be popular, it was declared by Dr. Fitch in his talk before the Hopkins student body at
the weekly assembly held yesterday.
'Pre-Natal Snobs'

These factors limit men to the
extent that they become "actually
prenatal snobs", asserted the speaker, prior to his declaration "the
truth does not make us free."
In discussing the freeing of man,
Dr. Fitch pointed out that when a
man is set free to do as he pleases,
he goes where he desires and rightfully belongs, and develops himself
for better or for worse.

New Interpretation

Mrs. William Vaughn Moody,
widow of the author, has shown
keen interest in the present production of this little played drama. She
has, in her correspondence with the
Playshop authorities, emphasized
the fact that in the past, too much
stress has been laid on the mystic
element in "The Faith Healer," to
the consequent neglect of the excellent love story it contains. The
latter, she contends, was meant by
her husband to take the lion's share
of importance, and it is one of the
purposes of the Playshop's performance to bring out, in its presentation, the correct interpretation.

Philippine. Commissioner
to Speak Here Sunday
"The World Colonial Situation"
will be the topic of an address to be
presented by the Honorable Camilo
Osias, Sunday, at 6 P. M., in
Levering Hall. This is the second
of a series of "Sunday Evenings"
sponsored by the Friendly Relations Committee.
Mr. Osias is Resident Commissioner from the Philippine Islands
and, in this capacity, represents the
islands in Congress. He was educated in the United States. It is
said he speaks the English language
fluently. Last year he spoke at the
"Y" International Thanksgiving
Dinner.
The lecture Sunday is open to
the student body.

Mrs. Molay to
Address Liberal Club
At the meeting of the Liberal
Club at 1 P. M. today, Mrs. William Molay of the Political Science
Department will speak on "Practical Politics."
Mrs. Molay is the wife of 'William Molay, Baltimcire attorney,
who ran against Governor Ritchie
in the Democratic gubernatorial
primaries of 1926.

Ambition Displayed by Johnny Green,
Mathematician, Believer and Univ. Porter
Johnny Green is a porter whose
domain is in the basement of Gilman Hall. Like the rest of his
colleagues of the University porters, he is of a deep chocolate hue.
But Johnny has other interests besides the sweeping, cleaning and
dusting of Gilman Hall. He has
something in common with the
itudents, too. Johnny is going
through the process of being educated.
Chez Johnny

A few days ago a NEWS-LETTER
reporter had occasion to enter the
little cubicle in the basement which
Johnny calls his office. Here, instead of being accosted by a conglomeration of brooms, brushes and
dustpans, as he opened the door he
was surprised to see Mr. Green
seated behind a rudely constructed
and impromptu desk, deeply absorbed in a consideration of mathematical problems. The reporter,
being interested in the reasons why
a porter should be studying math,
asked Johnny the whys and wherefores.
Green was born in Kokomo, Indiana, of Southern parents. His
grandparents were slaves; they and
his own parents were illiterate.

For the third time in four weeks
the Hopkins football team will meet
an opponent on a foreign gridiron.
The opposition tomorrow afternoon
will be the Pennsylvania Military
College eleven and the game will be
played at Chester, Pennsylvania.
This week's foe is rather puzzling, as their past performances
this season will show. After defeating Prospect Hill, 13 to 0, the
Cadets were defeated by Lehigh,
25 to 0, and took a 56-0 beating
from Gettysburg.:. With all Predictions unfavorable, the Chester gridders then pulled a Sur,pitige
.. by handing St. Joseph a trouncing to the
tune of 27 to 0. With their supporters much encouraged, the Soldiers then played a listless match
with Albright, losing a 42-7 game.
Then, as if to redeem themselves,
they held Dickinson 'Coileke to a
7-7 tie last Saturday after the latter
had been selected as the winner.
Inconsistency

With such inconsistency the Jays
hardly know what to expect tomorrow. Judging by the brand of
football produced against Albright
and Gettysburg, the Wad( and Blue
should win handily. However, the
Cadets may have another revival of
form in which case Hopkins may
be the victims of a surprise such as
was given St. Joseph's and Dickmson.
Lehigh's trouncing of the Penn
Soldiers took place the week before
they won an 18-to-12 victory over
Hopkins. In this comparison the
Jays look two or three touchdowns
better than the Cadets, but the
latter ate such
that it
is Unsafe to make. anYPrIedictions.

St. Johns Next,

Hopkins' team will get its last
test before meeting St. Johns. If
the attack can function as well as
it did against Haverford last Saturday night and the Jay defense can
keep the Pennsylvanians'from making any appreciable gains, chances
against the Johnnies will be much
brighter.
Lyons' kicking last week and the
work of Turnbull and Bauer in the
backfield were the high spots in the
Haverford game. Navy has contended that Lyons has no superior
in the State as a punter, ranking
him on a par with Bowstrom, captain of Navy's team this year. As
Brennan, who does the punting for
P. M. C., is supposed to be one of
the best in the vicinity of Philadelphia, there should be an interesting kicking duel tomorrow.

EDI1 ORIALS
TOO MUCH SPORT?
JOHNSON, Dean of Manchester, in an article
DR.in HEWLETT
the London Daily Mail last September, stated that an over
regard for sport was displacing the more vital interests of English
life. The worthy dean, who was himself a keen sportsman in his
younger days, said, "Wherever we go discussions turn primarily on
the results of the cricket matches and dirt-track races." The situation
in this country is not as bad as it is in England. Generally speaking,
the American is not as sport-minded as the Englishman.
However, in our own American universities this over-interest in
sport is prevalent. The great majority of students assume the roles
of observer, statistician and prophet instead of deriving the actual
physical benefit from the sports. This is due to the fact that our
athletic directors are more interested in the development of star players
and snappily functioning machines than in the physical development
of the majority of the student body. The percentage of actual participants in the athletics of any university is extremely small.
Major sports in the colleges are too spectacular. Every fall we become football crazy. Thousands of students and others pack stadiums
all over the country to sit huddled and shivering on hard benches in
order to watch a group of performers give themselves a workout.
Each play is discussed; figures from past generations are brought into
view. Here at the Hopkins, however, we are glad to note that this
situation is not carried out to the extent that it is at other so-called
institutions of learning.
The average college man has a great amount of leisure. How he
spends this leisure time will tell just what he gets out of his college
life. There are numerous ways of putting this additional time to good
use. Too little of it is spent in travel, which is the most broadening
of all educational pursuits. The average student does not devote much
time to reading, outside of that which is required. Far too little consideration is given to the arts, and yet the college man is supposed to
reflect culture. And then, far too little time outside of the classroom
is given to contacts with professors.
More attention at the Hopkins should be given to the physical development of the individual. A student needs a certain amount of
exercise in order to have a clear mind for his studies. A lack of
regular exercise leads to sluggishness in mental habits. It is needless
to say that this factor is sadly neglected by many students.
The appearance of a cage on the campus would be the best solution

BASKETBALL
Through the efforts of Coach
George Darley and Manager Kyle,
definite arrangements for the use
of the Loyola College gymnasium
by the Jay basket ball squad have
been made.
The Loyola squad will leave the
floor at 5:00 each afternoon, giving
Hopkins immediate use of it. Any
inconvenience occasioned by this
comparatively late starting- will be
alleviated by the accessibility of the
gym and by its warmth, the importance of which will be best appreciated by members of last year's
Carlin's-frozen squad. Coach Darley is particularly pleased with this
last feature, as he fully appreciates
how undesirable a cold floor can
be. The securing of the use of this
floor should be accompanied by additional spirit in practice and increased attendance at games, both
prime factors in the success of any
team.
This move should serve to cement
the amiable relations that have
existed between the two institutions
for the last several years. A game
with Loyola is included in the attractive schedule for this season,
which follows:
December 18—Temple University,
at Philadelphia.
January 6—Loyola College, at Baltimore.
January 9—Polytechnic Institute of
Brooklyn, at Brooklyn.
January 10—Army, at West Point.
January 15—Washington College,
at Baltimore.
January 20—Western Maryland, at
Baltimore.
January 22—University of Maryland, at Baltimore.
February 13—Washington College,
at Chestertown.
February 17—Wetsern Maryland,
at Westminster.
February 19—Loyola College, at
Baltimore.
February 25—University of Maryland, at College Park.

Metal on trial
In the laboratories of scores of foundries
and rolling mills,a constant search is being
conducted for a metal that is stronger,more
resistant to temperature strains,and more
economical to produce.Almostas constantly
the compounds and alloys so developed
are being brought to Crane Co. for trial.
The court that passes on them is composed
of the most experienced Crane designers,
metallurgists, and engineers. Under its
direction bars of the new metals are carefully tested for ductility,reduction ofarea,
elastic limit,and yield and breaking points.
Hardness, transverse strength, and
torsional strength are measured, behavior
under temperature strains is determined
by"I000 hour creep tests."
When the findings of all tests are favorable, the metals are made into valves and
fittings for trials in the Crane plant that
will approximate actual working conditions. Then Crane Co. sends out these
new materials to certain engineers who are
interested in advancing piping practice.
They use them in actual service; observing them over long periods, sending full
reports to Crane Co.
Notonly do materials thus developed serve
all industry. They have contributed to a
vast library of engineering data on metals
and their capabilities. Much ofthis is embodied in a book."Pioneering in Science",
a valuable reference manual for students.
Let us send it to you.

he goes where he desires and rightfully belongs, and develops himself
for better or for worse.

Mrs. William Vaughn Moody,
widow of the author, has shown
keen interest in the present production of this little played drama. She
has, in her correspondence with the
Playshop authorities, emphasized
the fact that in the past, too much
stress has been laid on the mystic
element in "The Faith Healer," to
the consequent neglect of the excellent love story it contains. The
latter, she contends, was meant by
her husband to take the lion's share
of importance, and it is one of the
purposes of the Playshop's performance to bring out, in its presentation, the correct interpretation.

Philippine. Commissioner
to Speak Here Sunday
"The World Colonial Situation"
will be the topic of an address to be
presented by the Honorable Camilo
Osias, Sunday, at 6 P. M., in
Levering Hall. This is the second
of a series of "Sunday Evenings"
sponsored by the Friendly Relations Committee.
Mr. Osias is Resident Commissioner from the Philippine Islands
and, in this capacity, represents the
islands in Congress. He was educated in the United States. It is
said he speaks the English language
fluently. Last year he spoke at the
"Y" International Thanksgiving
Dinner.
The lecture Sunday is open to
the student body.

Mrs. Molay to
Address Liberal Club
At the meeting of the Liberal
Club at 1 P. M. today, Mrs. William Molay of the Political Science
Department will speak on "Practical Politics."
Mrs. Molay is the wife of 'William Molay, Baltimcire attorney,
who ran against Governor Ritchie
in the Democratic gubernatorial
primaries of 1926.

Ambition Displayed by Johnny Green,
Mathematician, Believer and Univ. Porter
Johnny Green is a porter whose
domain is in the basement of Gilman Hall. Like the rest of his
colleagues of the University porters, he is of a deep chocolate hue.
But Johnny has other interests besides the sweeping, cleaning and
dusting of Gilman Hall. He has
something in common with the
itudents, too. Johnny is going
through the process of being educated.
Chez Johnny

A few days ago a NEWS-LETTER
reporter had occasion to enter the
little cubicle in the basement which
Johnny calls his office. Here, instead of being accosted by a conglomeration of brooms, brushes and
dustpans, as he opened the door he
was surprised to see Mr. Green
seated behind a rudely constructed
and impromptu desk, deeply absorbed in a consideration of mathematical problems. The reporter,
being interested in the reasons why
a porter should be studying math,
asked Johnny the whys and wherefores.
Green was born in Kokomo, Indiana, of Southern parents. His
grandparents were slaves; they and
his own parents were illiterate.

EDI1 ORIALS
TOO MUCH SPORT?
JOHNSON, Dean of Manchester, in an article
DR.in HEWLETT
the London Daily Mail last September, stated that an over
regard for sport was displacing the more vital interests of English
life. The worthy dean, who was himself a keen sportsman in his
younger days, said, "Wherever we go discussions turn primarily on
the results of the cricket matches and dirt-track races." The situation
in this country is not as bad as it is in England. Generally speaking,
the American is not as sport-minded as the Englishman.
However, in our own American universities this over-interest in
sport is prevalent. The great majority of students assume the roles
of observer, statistician and prophet instead of deriving the actual
physical benefit from the sports. This is due to the fact that our
athletic directors are more interested in the development of star players
and snappily functioning machines than in the physical development
of the majority of the student body. The percentage of actual participants in the athletics of any university is extremely small.
Major sports in the colleges are too spectacular. Every fall we become football crazy. Thousands of students and others pack stadiums
all over the country to sit huddled and shivering on hard benches in
order to watch a group of performers give themselves a workout.
Each play is discussed; figures from past generations are brought into
view. Here at the Hopkins, however, we are glad to note that this
situation is not carried out to the extent that it is at other so-called
institutions of learning.
The average college man has a great amount of leisure. How he
spends this leisure time will tell just what he gets out of his college
life. There are numerous ways of putting this additional time to good
use. Too little of it is spent in travel, which is the most broadening
of all educational pursuits. The average student does not devote much
time to reading, outside of that which is required. Far too little consideration is given to the arts, and yet the college man is supposed to
reflect culture. And then, far too little time outside of the classroom
is given to contacts with professors.
More attention at the Hopkins should be given to the physical development of the individual. A student needs a certain amount of
exercise in order to have a clear mind for his studies. A lack of
regular exercise leads to sluggishness in mental habits. It is needless
to say that this factor is sadly neglected by many students.
The appearance of a cage on the campus would be the best solution

BASKETBALL
Through the efforts of Coach
George Darley and Manager Kyle,
definite arrangements for the use
of the Loyola College gymnasium
by the Jay basket ball squad have
been made.
The Loyola squad will leave the
floor at 5:00 each afternoon, giving
Hopkins immediate use of it. Any
inconvenience occasioned by this
comparatively late starting- will be
alleviated by the accessibility of the
gym and by its warmth, the importance of which will be best appreciated by members of last year's
Carlin's-frozen squad. Coach Darley is particularly pleased with this
last feature, as he fully appreciates
how undesirable a cold floor can
be. The securing of the use of this
floor should be accompanied by additional spirit in practice and increased attendance at games, both
prime factors in the success of any
team.
This move should serve to cement
the amiable relations that have
existed between the two institutions
for the last several years. A game
with Loyola is included in the attractive schedule for this season,
which follows:
December 18—Temple University,
at Philadelphia.
January 6—Loyola College, at Baltimore.
January 9—Polytechnic Institute of
Brooklyn, at Brooklyn.
January 10—Army, at West Point.
January 15—Washington College,
at Baltimore.
January 20—Western Maryland, at
Baltimore.
January 22—University of Maryland, at Baltimore.
February 13—Washington College,
at Chestertown.
February 17—Wetsern Maryland,
at Westminster.
February 19—Loyola College, at
Baltimore.
February 25—University of Maryland, at College Park.

Metal on trial
In the laboratories of scores of foundries
and rolling mills,a constant search is being
conducted for a metal that is stronger,more
resistant to temperature strains,and more
economical to produce.Almostas constantly
the compounds and alloys so developed
are being brought to Crane Co. for trial.
The court that passes on them is composed
of the most experienced Crane designers,
metallurgists, and engineers. Under its
direction bars of the new metals are carefully tested for ductility,reduction ofarea,
elastic limit,and yield and breaking points.
Hardness, transverse strength, and
torsional strength are measured, behavior
under temperature strains is determined
by"I000 hour creep tests."
When the findings of all tests are favorable, the metals are made into valves and
fittings for trials in the Crane plant that
will approximate actual working conditions. Then Crane Co. sends out these
new materials to certain engineers who are
interested in advancing piping practice.
They use them in actual service; observing them over long periods, sending full
reports to Crane Co.
Notonly do materials thus developed serve
all industry. They have contributed to a
vast library of engineering data on metals
and their capabilities. Much ofthis is embodied in a book."Pioneering in Science",
a valuable reference manual for students.
Let us send it to you.
